title: 1.8.19: logging of "Setting new local account    address=0x..." never ending
body:
Hi there,

I upgraded my mainnet geth node from 1.8.12 to 1.8.19. After a simple `docker-compose down && docker-compose up -d` geth is stuck logging "Setting new local account    address=0x..." (20 new lines every second)

![screenshot from 2018-12-04 10-03-04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1733686/49430648-df24cf80-f7ab-11e8-9283-55c4971f922f.png)

![screenshot from 2018-12-04 10-00-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1733686/49430518-805f5600-f7ab-11e8-9dcf-be70742bf651.png)

#### System information

Geth version: `1.8.19`
OS & Version: Ubuntu 16.04 server

#### Actual behaviour
logging of "Setting new local account    address=0x..." never ending 

Thank you for you help

A few questions:

 * Are these accounts yours, or some random external ones?
 * Is your RPC port accessible from the internet?
 * Can you find a log with something along the lines of "transaction journal regenerated"?

here is a log excerpt:

```
INFO [12-04|11:06:16.036] Setting new local account                address=0x4b1E1A0A8fA88E6B73A19a2f7408c8e0CA0d7d79

INFO [12-04|11:06:16.121] Setting new local account                address=0x74d2BFa894681918f508F26eae743879510D4571

```

These accounts are not mine. The mainnet node has no account, no unlocked account.

Yes the RPC is accessible over internet. Here is the command I use to start the node:
`--syncmode "fast" --ws --wsaddr "0.0.0.0" --wsorigins "*"  --rpc --rpcaddr "0.0.0.0"`

But by default, personal api is not enabled, so I don't think anybody with RPC access could create a new account.

After about 10 minutes, the log message stops and I get the RPC access back:
```
Welcome to the Geth JavaScript console!

instance: Geth/v1.8.19-stable/linux-amd64/go1.11.2
 modules: eth:1.0 net:1.0 rpc:1.0 web3:1.0
```
Here is the log just before it stops logging about account creation:
```
INFO [12-04|11:14:12.355] Setting new local account                address=0x662a1B2510412E732148152BE84908C1fbC1dcC2
INFO [12-04|11:14:12.390] Setting new local account                address=0x0Ff58Ec76ACDF95563C4D4b0be85f394ff760Ba4

INFO [12-04|11:14:12.564] Setting new local account                address=0x4074DB50c1144393DD25807dE3E47769104aCaB7
INFO [12-04|11:14:12.600] Loaded local transaction journal         transactions=26954 dropped=0
INFO [12-04|11:14:12.809] Regenerated local transaction journal    transactions=26954 accounts=26939
WARN [12-04|11:14:12.821] Blockchain not empty, fast sync disabled 
INFO [12-04|11:14:13.211] New local node record                    seq=3 id=XXea15aa1ea0a6c9 ip=127.0.0.1 udp=30303 tcp=30303
INFO [12-04|11:14:13.219] IPC endpoint opened                      url=/root/.ethereum/geth.ipc
INFO [12-04|11:14:13.221] HTTP endpoint opened                     url=http://0.0.0.0:8545      cors= vhosts=xxx.xxx.xxx
INFO [12-04|11:14:13.221] WebSocket endpoint opened                url=ws://[::]:8546
INFO [12-04|11:14:13.237] Started P2P networking                   self=enode://4ee2XXXX712695fce33b73f9b16ec5e8b02debf388b6e821209f13827833f55459ce6f73f8a33f9ca12758b0fc84907XXXXXXXXXaa62380bd@127.0.0.1:30303
INFO [12-04|11:14:18.191] New local node record                    seq=4 id=XXea15aa1ea0a6c9 ip=X.X.X.X udp=1024  tcp=30303
INFO [12-04|11:15:43.391] Block synchronisation started 
WARN [12-04|11:16:00.555] Synchronisation failed, retrying         err="block download canceled (requested)"
WARN [12-04|11:18:43.878] Synchronisation failed, retrying         err="block download canceled (requested)"
INFO [12-04|11:19:49.088] Imported new chain segment               blocks=3 txs=352 mgas=17.043 elapsed=10.257s mgasps=1.662 number=6824065 hash=6d1b73…ad79d4 age=42m10s cache=1.84mB
INFO [12-04|11:19:51.966] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=65  mgas=7.988  elapsed=2.878s  mgasps=2.775 number=6824066 hash=438111…eddb0e age=41m42s cache=2.37mB
INFO [12-04|11:20:03.782] Imported new chain segment               blocks=3 txs=190 mgas=10.781 elapsed=11.811s mgasps=0.913 number=6824069 hash=46e89c…2fa08d age=41m19s cache=3.72mB
INFO [12-04|11:20:12.004] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=278 mgas=15.979 elapsed=8.221s  mgasps=1.943 number=6824071 hash=755665…0a0493 age=41m5s  cache=5.66mB
INFO [12-04|11:20:26.709] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=379 mgas=15.988 elapsed=14.705s mgasps=1.087 number=6824073 hash=553abd…154b94 age=40m53s cache=7.96mB
INFO [12-04|11:20:36.473] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=280 mgas=15.980 elapsed=9.764s  mgasps=1.637 number=6824075 hash=39f31b…7785f0 age=40m6s  cache=9.47mB
```

And no trace of "transaction journal regenerated" in the logs.

Thank you for you help

Actually, there is:

```
INFO [12-04|11:14:12.809] Regenerated local transaction journal    transactions=26954 accounts=26939
```

The transaction pool is tracking a slew of account as local, so when you start up your node, it's reimporting all the transactions that have been considered local (they get saved to disk). That's where the logs originate from.

Now, the reason these transactions are considered local is probably because your RPC port is open from the internet and somebody is using your node to send transactions. Anything (by default) sent through your node will cause it to mark the origin account as a local one.

First thing's first, you need to get rid of this transaction journal. You can do that by stopping your node and deleting the `transactions.rlp` file from your data directory.

Next, you need to decide whether you want to permit random people from the internet sending transactions through your node or not. If not, you need to close down the port. If you don't care, you can run geth with `--txpool.nolocals` to disable racking local transactions.

my bad, I did grep on "regenerated" instead of "Regenerated", that's why...

Some of my services use this node to send transactions. The node is open through a unique DNS (not ip) that is "kept secret", so I don't think someone else (apart my services) is using this node (though I'm not 100% sure...)

I will run geth with `--txpool.nolocals` then, thanks a lot for your help!
